articles.title: Reining in emission now can cut 0.6m of future sea-level rise: Study
articles.summary: Greenhouse gas emissions from 2020 to 2050 commit the world to an additional 0.3 metres of sea-level rise by 2300. If emissions continue on their current trajectory until 2090, the world would face a global rise of about 0.8 metres. Around 0.6 metres of this increase could be avoided if immediate emissions reductions consistent with the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C pathway are implemented.

articles.title: Spring's migratory flocks pose bird flu risk for Tasmania
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Migratory birds are returning to Tasmania during a period of increased bird flu. The chance of the virus affecting the state's coastal areas is on the rise, according to the state health minister, Mark Blythe.      .

articles.title: The city that everyone thought was cheap is now Australia's second most expensive
articles.author: Emily Rayner
articles.summary: Sydney is the world's second most expensive housing market, behind only Hong Kong. Demographia International Housing Affordability Report says Adelaide has become the nation's second least affordable city. Perth remains the most affordable of Australia's five major capitals at 8.3 times income. Australia's national median multiple now sits at 9.7, far worse than Canada, UK (5.6), or the US (4.8).

articles.title: Minister downplays risk of bird flu after seal deaths
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: "We cannot stop this coming to mainland Australia because it would come via migratory birds if it was to come," she said.    “We can't stop it coming because it's a migratory bird’s migration.”

articles.title: Minister downplays risk of bird flu after seal deaths
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: Heard Island elephant seal pups died of H5 bird flu. The H5 strain has been detected on the French Kerguelen and Crozet islands, 450km away. The government has pledged more than $100 million to enhance bird flu preparedness and response. Environmental groups warn that more surveillance and boots on the ground are needed to prepare the nation for bird flu's arrival.

articles.title: Minister downplays risk of bird flu after seal deaths
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: The federal government has downplayed any imminent risk of bird flu reaching Australia despite an unusual number of deaths in elephant seal pups on the sub-Antarctic territory of Heard Island, despite the fact that there is a problem with elephant seal deaths on the Heard Island.

articles.title: Minister downplays risk of bird flu after seal deaths
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: Elephant seal pups died on Heard Island. The H5 bird flu strain has been detected on the French Kerguelen and Crozet islands less than 450 km away. Australia is the only continent free from the H5 strain, which has killed millions of birds and marine life. The federal government has pledged more than $100 million to enhance bird flu preparedness.

articles.title: Heavy rains flatten acres of paddy in Tungabhadra basin
articles.author: DHNS
articles.summary: Coffee and pepper growers in Kodagu, Hassan and Chikkamagaluru districts are staring at losses due to a prolonged wet spell. The weather has been wet in the last few days in these districts.       .

articles.title: Australia fiddles with fossil gas while the country swelters in record heat. It doesn't make sense
articles.author: Bill Hare
articles.summary: Global warming has reached an average of nearly 1.5C and will reach at least 2.7C by the end of the century if we don't take more action. The biggest barrier to the global energy revolution is the fossil fuel industry and its relationship with governments. Fossil fuel industry needs to be reduced rapidly and effectively out of the energy system by 2050 and the power sector a decade earlier.

articles.title: Why Climate Alarmists Are Bad for the Developing World
articles.author: Patrick Keeney
articles.summary: There are moral and practical costs that climate alarmism places on the developing world, writes Simon Tisdall. He points out that the debate about climate change doesn't pay enough attention to this aspect of it.  It's important to pay attention to the moral, practical costs.

articles.title: Sub-Antarctic Sub-Region Detected with Dangerous Bird Flu H5 Strain: Concerns Heightened by its Presence on Heard Island in the Southern Ocean
articles.author: Omar El Sayed
articles.summary: There are suspected cases of bird flu on Heard Island, a remote sub-Antarctic territory in Australia. The H5N1 strain has affected over 97 million birds in the US as of October 2024. The WHO is concerned that the virus could affect Australian poultry industries and wild bird populations.

articles.title: Claws out: booming population of red crabs on the march
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: More than 100 million red crabs are making their annual trek from Christmas Island's rainforest to the coast every year. The migration spectacle occupies countless bucket lists and tourists are keen to take part in the annual event.    i.e. to see the migration spectacle.

articles.title: Claws out: booming population of red crabs on the march
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: The island is expected to experience more severe dry periods as global temperatures rise and more intense downpours once crabs arrive. It is not yet clear if and how climate change is impacting crabs or their migration patterns, although Mr Tiernan said the island will experience more dry periods.

articles.title: APTOPIX Climate Heat Farmworkers Study
articles.author: JCH
articles.summary: Manuel Gallegos carries a cooler and a large umbrella while leaving a sugarcane field in Niland, California, on Thursday, Sept. 11, 2025. APTOPIX Climate Heat Farmworkers Study is based on data from a study of farmworkers in California.

articles.title: Comfort food: Western NC chef pushes past Hurricane Helene through culinary delights
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Jennifer Currie's devotion to cooking increased during Hurricane Helene. Her dishes served as a positive outlet during a turbulent time in her hometown of Clyde, Western North Carolina.    .      "Comfort food" is a Western NC chef's term for cooking.

articles.title: Urgent Alert: Deadly Bird Flu Threatens Australian Borders with Rapid Spread Potential
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Scientists are concerned H5N1 bird flu has spread among elephant seals on Heard Island. The majority of mortalities were detected in elephant seal pups and in a small number of adults on the island's south-east coast. If the disease has spread, it could spread to Australia via migratory birds. Australia's agricultural industry has been bracing for an outbreak, with the government investing more than $100 million into preparedness and response capability.

articles.title: Climate Heat Farmworkers Study
articles.author: JCH
articles.summary: Climate Heat Farmworkers Study research assistant Briana Toji straps a wearable heat-stress monitor on farmworker Hipolito Hernandez in a sugarcane field in Niland, California, on Thursday, Sept. 11, 2025. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong)

articles.title: Tasmania remains free of H5 bird flu, but returning migratory birds could pose a risk
articles.author: André Leslie
articles.summary: As spring arrives in Tasmania, the threat of bird flu remains present via the state's rugged coastlines. Long-distance migratory birds like shearwaters and bar-tailed godwits are touching down after finishing their migratory journeys from the United States and Russia. Scientists are investigating whether the H5 bird flu has reached the distant Australian sub-Antarctic territory of Heard Island. The suspected arrival of the virus cannot be confirmed until the ship returns to Australia in mid-November.

articles.title: Heavy rains cause landslides and partial collapse of bridge in Quiviján, Baracoa
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The main bridge in Quiviján, Baracoa, Cuba, suffered a partial collapse due to heavy rains. The rains caused landslides on mountain roads and blocked sections of the main highway and secondary roads. The rise in stream levels saturated the drainage system, causing flooding in populated areas. Tropical Storm Melissa could become a category 3 hurricane and hit Cuba on Wednesday as a powerful hurricane.

articles.title: Virtual reality can help people understand and care about distant communities
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: For many people, climate change feels like a distant threat, something that will happen in the future somewhere far away to people we know little. For others, it's a problem that affects them now and in the near future, not in the here and now.

articles.title: The aerosol paradox Saudi Arabia can help the world manage
articles.author: Arab News
articles.summary: The year 2024 was the warmest ever recorded. Global average temperatures reached 15.10°C, about 1.60°C above the 1850-1900 pre-industrial baseline. It was the first time the world spent an entire year above 1.5°C.

articles.title: Police say one person arrested after wildfire sparked in Kelowna, B.C.
articles.author: Brenna Owen
articles.summary: The road is closed at Bamfield Main due to the Mount Underwood wildfire south of Port Alberni, B.C., on Saturday, Aug. 16, 2025. The Canadian Press gives free access to subscribers who gift this article to friends and family for free.

articles.title: Main road to Vancouver Island community reopens after wildfire damage
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: The road is closed at Bamfield Main due to the Mount Underwood wildfire south of Port Alberni, B.C., on Saturday, Aug. 16, 2025. The Canadian Press gives free access to subscribers who gift this article to friends and family for free.

articles.title: How climate change poses a national security threat
articles.author: Devika Rao
articles.summary: Climate change increases the world's instability and worsens national security. The U.S. faces a 'compounding threat' when it comes to conflict, disease, migration, poverty and the ability of the military to operate effectively globally. The Trump administration has been known to deny climate change and curtail programs dedicated to the environment or aid.

articles.title: AGRICULTURE: Government, Stakeholders Embrace Climate Vulnerability Mapping
articles.author: Dickens H Okello
articles.summary: The Ministry of Agriculture and sector stakeholders have embraced climate vulnerability mapping and risk profiles to design evidence-based adaptation interventions to ensure quality yields and livelihoods. Climate change has affected rainfall patterns and amplified risks from pests, diseases, droughts, and floods making traditional methods inadequate to maintain yields.

articles.title: New study: rainforests contributing to carbon emissions
articles.summary: Australia's tropical rainforests have become a net source of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. The study was published in Nature this week. It is the first of their kind globally to show this response to climate change. Dr Hannah Carle talks to Mihingarangi about the significance of these findings.

articles.title: The aerosol paradox Saudi Arabia can help the world manage
articles.author: Hassan Alzain
articles.summary: The year 2024 was the warmest ever recorded. Global average temperatures reached 15.10°C, about 1.60°C above the 1850-1900 pre-industrial baseline. Human-made aerosols, including particles from shipping, agriculture, and dust, have been shading the planet. They scatter sunlight and brighten clouds, masking 0.4 to 0.5°C of warming. As they decline, Earth is losing one of its few natural buffers against rising heat. According to the State of Global Air 2024 report, air pollution caused an estimated 8.1 million deaths in 2021.

articles.title: Severe heatwave warnings remain in place across Queensland and NT while the south shiver through sub-zero mornings and snow
articles.author: Conor Breslin
articles.summary: Temperatures will remain above 40°C across the Northern Territory and Queensland until Sunday. Brisbane will reach 37°C, which is 11 degrees above average for this time of the year. A severe to extreme heatwave warning remains in force from Friday to Sunday. The southern states are experiencing sub-zero mornings. Cold fronts are expected to deepen the chill into early next week.

articles.title: Stock Market Insights: Is rising market turbulence a real trend or just isolated events
articles.author: Richard Baker
articles.summary: There are two kinds of turbulence: natural turbulence caused by weather and pilot-induced turbulence, which happens when a pilot makes a mistake. We are beginning to see some increased turbulence (market volatility), but is it a change to overall market conditions or a few isolated mistakes by companies?

articles.title: Global warming is reshaping extreme precipitation events across Northern Hemisphere
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: As global warming continues to reshape Earth's climate, both the occurrence and mechanisms of extreme weather are becoming more likely.    .   in the world's climate is changing due to global warming and extreme weather.  in this way, extreme weather is more likely to occur.

articles.title: Adverse weather disrupts fishing in Uttara Kannada
articles.author: TNN
articles.summary: The govt. has imposed a two-day ban on deep-sea fishing for fishermen along the Karnataka coast. Strong winds and towering waves have made deep sea fishing perilous, forcing many fishing boats to return to the safety of ports. The new fishing season began three months ago, but continuous weather disruptions have prevented fishermen from fishing.

articles.title: Impending Cyclonic Storm Set to Drench Odisha and Parts of West Bengal
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: A newly-formed low-pressure system over the Bay of Bengal is expected to develop into a cyclonic storm by October 27. This system could bring extreme weather conditions from October 27 to 29. Authorities have issued a yellow weather alert for upcoming days, noting uncertainty in landfall predictions but significant rain in coastal districts. IMD has issued severe weather warnings.

articles.title: Climate Divide: Inequality & a Warming World
articles.summary: Megha Majumdar's upcoming novel, A Guardian and a Thief, is set in Kolkata in 2023. It's a warning about the climate-altered future depicted in the novel. The number of people displaced by climate-related disasters is projected to exceed 216 million globally by 2050, according to the World Bank. The novel's portrayal of the emotional toll of leaving one's homeland resonates deeply.

articles.title: Cyclone Montha: Tamil Nadu Braces for Impact Amidst Monsoon Rains
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: A low-pressure area over the Bay of Bengal is poised to develop into Cyclone Montha by October 27. The weather system promises to bring significant rainfall to Tamil Nadu. The IMD has advised fishermen against venturing into the sea until October 28. The state's disaster management plans are in full effect.

articles.title: Bird flu warning as strain suspected on remote island
articles.summary: Heard Island in the sub-Antarctic has signs of H5 avian influenza for the first time. Australia is the only continent free from the strain. The federal government has pledged more than $100 million to enhance bird flu preparedness and response. Invasive Species Council policy director Carol Booth says more investment is needed.

articles.title: $239K Oceanfront Cape Cod Home Teetering on the Edge of Eroding Bluff Attracts Offers From Builders
articles.author: Kellie Speed
articles.summary: A Cape Cod cottage perched high atop a crumbling bluff on the verge of collapsing into the Atlantic Ocean is on the market for $239,000. The house was built in 1956 and last traded hands in 2020 for $450,000, but the current owner has lost 16 feet from the house to the edge of the bluff due to rising sea levels. Retired builders are interested in buying the house.

articles.title: Bird flu warning as strain suspected on remote island
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: H5 avian flu has been observed for the first time on Australia's Heard Island in the sub-Antarctic. Australia is the only continent free from the strain, which has killed millions of birds globally and marine life including seals. The federal government has pledged more than $100 million to enhance bird flu preparedness and response. Invasive Species Council policy director Carol Booth says more investment is needed.

articles.title: Ask a Master Gardener: Feeding hummingbirds
articles.author: Bonnie Courter Master Gardner
articles.summary: This year I've been successful in attracting hummingbirds to my feeders. I thoroughly enjoy watching them and so do my children. With winter and freezing temperatures approaching, I wonder if I should keep feeding them or do they all start migrating south? I don't know.

articles.title: Why Southern California's farming regions are becoming deadly hotspots for farmworkers
articles.author: Dorany Pineda and Jae C. Hong
articles.summary: Temperatures in Southern California have increased since the start of the 20th century. Seven of the last eight years through 2024 were the warmest on record. Southern California is heating up twice as fast as Northern California. About 17,579 migrant and seasonal farmworkers were employed in Imperial County from 2023-24. Researchers from San Diego State University are mapping areas of extreme heat in the Imperial and Coachella valleys.

articles.title: Antarctic Amundsen-Scott Station Sees Coldest October in 44 Years…Mainstream Media Silent!
articles.author: P Gosselin
articles.summary: The Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station registered a temperature of minus 61.3 degrees Celsius on October 15th. It was the coldest October at the station since 1981. CNN reported in 2021 that the continent had experienced its coldest winter since records began. Report 24 argues that this recurring cold record is a 'nail in the coffin of the CO₂ dogma'

articles.title: Extreme heat impact as PH reaches boiling point
articles.author: Ludwig Federigan
articles.summary: A decade ago, the world signed the Paris Agreement on climate change. Since 2015, global temperatures have risen by an average of 11 degrees Celsius. Extreme heat contributes to an estimated 500,000 deaths worldwide annually. In the Philippines, the government's National Adaptation Plan (2023-2050) aims to fortify the nation against such climate impacts.

articles.title: Fears highly contagious virus spreading after hundreds of seal pups found dead
articles.author: Peter Hobson
articles.summary: Hundreds of seal pups have been found dead on Heard Island in the sub-Antarctic. Australia's agriculture department is sending samples from the dead seals for urgent testing. The virulent H5N1 strain has caused millions of deaths among wild birds and mammals since 2021. Australia is the only continent free of the virus.

articles.title: Women's Cricket World Cup 2025: SL vs PAK Abandoned 🏏🌧️
articles.author: Luis Mendoza
articles.summary: Seven out of eleven matches at the recent Women's World Cup in Colombo were disrupted by rain. The future of outdoor sports is about adapting to an unpredictable environment. UN Environment Programme estimates that climate change could render some traditional sporting venues unusable within decades. Sports organizations should conduct climate risk assessments for all venues.

articles.title: Indian Farmers Struggle as Climate Change Warps Landscape
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Indian Farmers Struggle as Climate Change Warps Landscape Foreign Policy because of the impact of climate change on farmers' livelihoods, especially in India's farming sector.       .   for more information, go to: http://www.indianfarmers.org/news/environmental-policy/climate-change/

articles.title: Indian Farmers Struggle as Climate Change Warps Landscape
articles.author: James Moules
articles.summary: Climate change is changing the landscape of India's agriculture and forcing farmers to adapt to a changing environment. The percentage of population living in urban areas is expected to rise from 28% in 2000 to 37% in 2024. Rural areas are struggling with a loss of labor and a rapidly shifting environment.

articles.title: Less green space in Broxtowe than English average according to Friends of the Earth
articles.author: Data Reporter
articles.summary: People in Broxtowe have less local green space than the average across England, according to a new analysis by Friends of the Earth. The charity warns the risks of climate change are already a reality for millions across England. The Government's revised climate plan is due next Wednesday.

articles.title: More green space in Bassetlaw than English average according to Friends of the Earth
articles.author: Adam Care
articles.summary: People in Bassetlaw have access to more local green space than the average across England, new analysis shows. The figures come from a new analysis of environmental threats by charity Friends of the Earth. It was released ahead of the Government's publication of its revised climate plan, due next Wednesday.

articles.title: Hurricane Wilma's Legacy: South Florida 20 Years Later
articles.author: Kartik Krishnaiyer
articles.summary: 20 years ago today, on October 24, 2005, Hurricane Wilma made landfall near Cape Romano, Florida. It carved a path across the Florida peninsula, leaving behind a trail of destruction. For example, the key long-term effects of Wilma is how it forced Florida's and emergency systems to rethink.

articles.title: Species added to extinction list
articles.author: Dinah Voyles Pulver
articles.summary: IUCN has added ten species of animals and plants to the list of extinct species, including the slender-billed curlew, a migratory shorebird last seen in Morocco in 1995 and now considered extinct. More than half of bird species globally are in decline, according to the IUCN. Communities and businesses near national parks are feeling the effects of the government shutdown, which is in its fourth week.

articles.title: South Korea is losing more fishermen at sea – [your]NEWS
articles.author: Praise Dominic
articles.summary: 164 people died or vanished at sea around South Korea in the past year. The toll was dominated by fishermen whose boats sank or capsized. Many in the industry blame a warming climate. The government has launched a formal review. The chair of its taskforce cited climate change, an ageing workforce, dependence on migrant labour and weak safety practice.

articles.title: Trump knows climate change is real — that's why he wants to mine Greenland
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: New Study Finds 75% Of Rising Ocean Heat Likely Natural, CO2 Not A Factor
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: According to Levitus et al. (2012), the 1955-2010 temperature increase corresponding to the rise in OHC amounts to just 0.09°C in the 0-2,000 m layer. Three-fourths of the rising OHC trend since 1955 must be natural or due to the 'rising solar input' associated with the decline in cloud albedo.

articles.title: In a California farming region, researchers are mapping rural heat to protect farmworkers
articles.summary: Researchers from San Diego State University are mapping extreme heat areas in California's Imperial Valley to protect farmworkers from rising temperatures due to climate change and greenhouse gas emissions. The Imperial Valley has over 123 days annually with temperatures exceeding 95°F, with a growing number of heat-related illnesses among farmworkers.

articles.title: Two Major Coral Species Now Functionally Extinct In Florida Keys, After Record-Breaking Marine Heatwave
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: 2023's record-breaking marine heatwave on Florida's coral reef drove two of the area's key coral species to functional extinction. Staghorn and elkhorn numbers had been dwindling even before the 2023 heatwave. The rest of this article is behind a paywall.

articles.title: How does the South Carolina drought compare to historical events?
articles.author: Andrew Wulfeck
articles.summary: According to the latest U.S. Drought Monitor, more than three-fourths of South Carolina is experiencing abnormally dry conditions. The driest conditions are centered west of Interstate 95, with the most severe areas located near Rock Hill, south of the North Carolina border, and the region between Augusta and Charleston. The drought is not as severe as the one experienced earlier in the year or during historical episodes.

articles.title: Heat and humidity is a lethal mix for SA's small birds
articles.author: Sheree Bega
articles.summary: Researchers studied blue waxbills that were most affected in South Africa's first documented heat-related mortality event involving wild birds in late 2020. They found that humidity significantly reduced their capacity to cool themselves through evaporation. The study reinforces calls for climate adaptation strategies that incorporate humidity into wildlife vulnerability models.

articles.title: Melissa to strengthen into major hurricane
articles.author: Kenton Gewecke
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is expected to strengthen into a major hurricane this weekend. It is forecast to bring heavy rains to the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Jamaica. An elderly man in Haiti was killed by a downed tree due to the storm. It's expected to cross southern Cuba and out into the Atlantic.

articles.title: Report calls for full inclusion of community voices in addressing climate change in Kenya
articles.author: STAR REPORTER
articles.summary: Voices for Just Climate Action (VCA) is a coalition working to ensure that climate solutions in Kenya are people-centred, locally-led, and grounded in justice. Today, VCA launched a publication profiling how communities across 17 counties in the country are driving local solutions aimed at addressing climate change.

articles.title: Heat in Japan disrupts fruit and vegetable production
articles.summary: Temperatures rose sharply in 2023 and have remained elevated since. The number of summer days exceeding 35°C continues to increase. Warmer sea temperatures near the Philippines raise air pressure over Japan, resulting in extended sunny periods. As temperatures rise, humidity also increases, causing heavier rainfall events. The climate is shifting toward higher temperatures and more erratic rainfall patterns, creating ongoing challenges for agricultural production.

articles.title: Featured Valle Country Fair return breaks 12-year attendance record Nick Fogleman Oct 24, 2025 29 mins ago 0 3 min to read Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email
articles.author: Boone Mountain Times
articles.summary: The Valle Country Fair returned with record attendance and fundraising to benefit outreach programs of Holy Cross Episcopal Church and the Valle Crucis Conference Center. The fair is jointly sponsored by the two organizations. Proceeds from the fair will support outreach programs in Watauga, Avery and Ashe counties.

articles.title: Kerala to frame new land use policy, forms expert panel
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: The Planning and Economic Affairs department has constituted an expert panel for drafting a new land use policy. The panel includes representatives of 20 government departments and agencies. The State Action Plan on Climate Change 2023-2030 (SAPCC 2.0) had noted that Kerala needs a 'comprehensive review' of its land use planning.

articles.title: Why is Switzerland warming faster than most countries in the world?
articles.author: Open In The Local App
articles.summary: June 2025 was the second-warmest month in Switzerland since temperature measurements began in 1864. Human-caused climate change is accelerating global warming. The north side of the Swiss Alps has warmed more than the south over the past 150 years. The reason for this is the presence of mountain regions.

articles.title: China's coastal cities are sinking as seas rise at record speed
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Sea levels are rising faster than at any time in 4,000 years. China's coastal cities are at particular risk due to the rapid increase in sea levels, according to scientists. The rapid increase is driven by climate change, they say. The rise is especially affecting coastal cities in China.

articles.title: Scientists in Switzerland say 1.5C climate change goal is out of reach: Survey
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Climate scientists in Switzerland do not expect the world to limit warming to 1.5C (2.7F) under the Paris Agreement. They believe the Earth will warm by around 2.5 C (4.5F) by the end of this century.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu Gears Up for Cyclonic Storm with Comprehensive Readiness Measures
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Greater Chennai Corporation (GCC) has mobilized resources to manage potential emergencies. The India Meteorological Department is forecasting heavy rainfall due to an approaching cyclonic storm. Relief camps and community kitchens have been established to support affected citizens, while over 24,000 personnel are prepared to conduct relief and rescue operations.

articles.title: Jamaica has a rich hurricane history but has avoided most powerful storms
articles.author: Jesse Ferrell
articles.summary: Melissa is forecast to pass close to Jamaica as a powerful Category 4 storm. The island has never recorded a direct landfall from a Category 4 or 5 hurricane. Four Category 3 hurricanes have hit Jamaica since NHC records began. Three Category 4 hurricanes have tracked close to the island since 2000.

articles.title: Exxon's 1980s climate prediction
articles.author: Brian J Karem
articles.summary: In an excerpt from 'Just Ask the Question', Bonni Cohen, Jon Shenk and Pedro Kos talk about THE WHITE HOUSE EFFECT by veteran documentarians. It has been a long time since we discovered a problem with Global Warming. Scientists from the oil companies helped discover the problem.

articles.title: Will Tropical Storm Melissa become strongest storm of season? See what Florida can expect
articles.author: News Journal
articles.summary: Melissa is expected to rapidly intensify into a powerful hurricane with devastating Caribbean impacts. AccuWeather meteorologists are expecting life-threatening flooding in Jamaica, the Dominican Republic and Cuba, leading to a potential humanitarian crisis in the days ahead. Melissa is also expected to cause catastrophic flash flooding and landslides.

articles.title: Birding: What is a songbird?
articles.author: Kim O'Brien Root
articles.summary: The living birds are classified into about 45 groups of related species called 'orders'. Orders are broken down further into families. For example, the Anseriformes contains three families of waterfowl: the screamers of South America, the magpie geese of Australia, and the ducks, geese and swans.

articles.title: Birding: What is a songbird?
articles.author: Kim O'Brien Root
articles.summary: Dan Cristol teaches in the biology department at William & Mary and can be contacted at dacris@wm.edu. Dan Cristol is also a member of the William and Mary Bird Club. He recommends visiting local birding clubs to find out about birding opportunities.

articles.title: When is daylight saving 2025? Here's when we 'fall back' an hour
articles.author: Alexis Simmerman
articles.summary: Austin is on track to have its warmest October on record with an average temperature of 80.3 degrees. This year, daylight saving time began on March 9 and will end on Sunday, Nov. 2. Arizona and Hawaii are the only U.S. states that have never changed their clocks for the practice. The Navajo Nation hasn't either.

articles.title: SEPA issues flood warning in Easter Ross
articles.author: Lauren Cameron
articles.summary: The Scottish Environment Protection Agency has issued an alert. Residents are advised to remain vigilant and take steps to protect themselves and their property. The alert is in force until further notice. The Floodline quick dial number for this area is 22200. The map of affected areas is available on the SEPA website.

articles.title: In a California farming region, researchers are mapping rural heat to protect farmworkers
articles.author: Dorany Pineda
articles.summary: Southern California is heating up twice as fast as Northern California. Warming has accelerated and seven of the last eight years have been warmest on record in the state. The hot climate makes it dangerous for farmworkers, who are increasingly vulnerable to rising temperatures due to greenhouse gas emissions from burning coal, oil and natural gas. Researchers from San Diego State University are working to understand the health consequences of heat stress on farmworkers.

articles.title: In a California farming region, researchers are mapping rural heat to protect farmworkers
articles.author: Dorany Pineda
articles.summary: Researchers from San Diego State University are working to understand how climate change is impacting heat in rural areas and farmworkers who toil there.    The research is focusing on some of the most agriculturally rich regions in the U.S. and their farmworkers.

articles.title: In a California farming region, researchers are mapping rural heat to protect farmworkers
articles.summary: Temperatures in Southern California have increased almost 3 F since the start of the 20th century. Seven of the last eight years through 2024 were the warmest on record in California. Farmworkers in the Imperial and Coachella valleys are more vulnerable to heat stress due to climate change. Researchers from San Diego State University have collected data from 300 farmworkers.

articles.title: Sydney Weather Forecast For India vs Australia, 3rd ODI: Will Rain Play Spoilsport at SCG?
articles.author: Ankit Banerjee
articles.summary: India lost back-to-back matches against Australia in the three-match ODI series. The final ODI takes place at the Sydney Cricket Ground on Saturday (October 25th) with temperatures around the 16-23 degrees Celsius. The humidity is likely to be between 56-69 per cent and the wind will gradually pick up as the day progresses.

articles.title: Multi-Century Sea-Level Rise Tied to Emissions
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: New study shows how the Earth's sea-level rise is intricately linked to cumulative greenhouse gas emissions emitted within the next few decades. The research is based on the MAGICC (Model for the Assessment of Greenhouse-gas Induced Climate Change) version 7.5.3. It has been validated up to the year 2300.

articles.title: Renewable Friday: More and Faster Everything, Now!!!
articles.author: Mokurai
articles.summary: The amount of bogosity in proposals for new nuclear reactors has been growing exponentially. US govt. approval under Trump is inherently bogus, especially with ¾ of the nuclear safety force fired. The American Council on Renewable Energy (ACORE) is a bad idea.

articles.title: Emission cuts before mid-century could prevent 0.6 meters of future sea-level rise
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: the rising seas are irreversible on human timescales and among the most severe.   in the modern timescares and among most severe seas.  in human timescale. The most severe and irreversible on humans timescaren't the worst seas  in future.

articles.title: Missouri may see mild temps as La Niña slowly develops
articles.author: KTTN News
articles.summary: A La Niña weather pattern has emerged in the Pacific Ocean. It will take several weeks for it to influence the weather in Missouri. The weather outcomes remain variable and could shift quickly once the pattern strengthens. Missouri is expected to continue experiencing above-average temperatures through mid-November.

articles.title: Extinction rates have slowed. But are humans off the hook?
articles.author: Liam Gilliver
articles.summary: Extinction rates have slowed across many plant and animal groups despite claims that the planet is experiencing another 'mass extinction'. Extinctions in plants, arthropods and land vertebrates peaked around 100 years ago, and have since declined. Most extinct species are molluscs and vertebrates on islands, but most threatened species today live on the mainland and are at risk due to habitat destruction.

articles.title: South Sudan: Effects of climate change hitting harder
articles.author: APA-Juba
articles.summary: Floods have displaced over 43,000 people in the Greater Pibor Administrative Area of South Sudan due to climate change. A cordon built by South Korean peacekeepers under the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) is the only protection for the airport, parts of the market, and key administrative buildings in the area. The dyke is also a vital barrier against rising floodwaters.

articles.title: 14 U.S. States Most Likely To Survive A Global Climate Crisis
articles.author: Drea Rose
articles.summary: Some U.S. states are better positioned to cope with climate change than others due to their geographical location, resources, and adaptability. Vermont, Oregon, Washington, Minnesota and Colorado are some of the states that are well-suited for climate change adaptation.

articles.title: Global warming pushes Earth's tipping points toward critical thresholds
articles.author: Yesim Yuksel
articles.summary: Rising global temperatures are driving the planet's tipping points toward critical thresholds that could trigger irreversible climate changes, according to Levent Kurnaz, director of Bogazici University's Center for Climate Change and Policy Research. His remarks followed the release of the Global Tipping Points Report 2025. The report highlights escalating risks to coral reefs, the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), mountain glaciers, and the Amazon rainforest.

articles.title: Hurricanes, the Calusa and what we can learn
articles.summary: The southwest coast of Florida is a hurricane hotspot between June and November each year. The Calusa lived there for nearly 2,000 years. Their success was due to their deep environmental knowledge, innovative land and seascape infrastructure, and cultivation of social capital within and between communities.

articles.title: Hurricanes, the Calusa and what we can learn
articles.summary: The southwest coast of Florida is a hurricane hotspot between June and November each year. The Calusa lived there for nearly 2,000 years. Their success was due to their deep environmental knowledge, innovative land and seascape infrastructure, and cultivation of social capital within and between communities.

articles.title: Why Food Resilience and Security Must Be a Cornerstone at COP30
articles.author: Fadeke Banjo
articles.summary: Food resilience and equitable climate action aim for just and regenerative food systems that benefit both people and the planet. World leaders must find the political will to commit resources to address climate change while including the most vulnerable countries and communities in shaping the solutions. Small-holder farmers play a crucial role in global food production systems, providing access to nutritious and affordable foods to local communities, increasing employment numbers in rural areas, and boosting local economies. Brazil's current food system plays a significant role in deforestation, which accelerates climate change.

articles.title: Hundreds of seal pups likely killed by deadly disease sweeping the globe
articles.author: Peter Hobson
articles.summary: Hundreds of seal pups have been found dead on Heard Island in the sub-Antarctic. Australia's agriculture department is sending samples from the dead seals for urgent testing. The virulent H5N1 strain has caused millions of deaths among wild birds and mammals since 2021. Australia is the only continent free of the virus.

articles.title: ILO: Climate Challenges Linked to Green Jobs in Arab States
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Today is International Climate Action Day. ILO Regional Office for Arab States launched a series of factsheets on Employment, Environment and Climate Nexus Factsheets for 12 countries in the region. It is the first regional evidence base linking labour market dynamics, environmental performance and climate vulnerability. The data shows that climate change and environmental degradation are directly impacting employment and productivity, especially in sectors such as agriculture, construction and energy. Some of the conflict-affected countries are among the most climate-vulnerable in the world, while Gulf countries demonstrate stronger institutional readiness.

articles.title: Bird flu fears rise after hundreds of seal pups found dead on Australia's sub-Antarctic island
articles.summary: Hundreds of dead seal pups have been found on Heard Island in the sub-Antarctic with signs that suggest they were killed by H5N1 bird flu. The virus has spread through wild bird and mammal populations since 2021, killing millions and infecting poultry and dairy farms. Australia is the only continent free of the virus.

articles.title: Urgent Deep Emission Reductions by Mid-Century Key to Minimizing Long-Term
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Rising seas represent one of the most profound and irreversible impacts of climate change. New research shows that greenhouse gas emissions will set sea-level rise trajectories for centuries to come. There is an urgent need for climate mitigation efforts to limit temperature increases and safeguard coastal regions against long-term inundation.

articles.title: TMID Editorial: Climate change and small islands
articles.summary: The Mediterranean region is warming at twice the global average rate. The region is experiencing longer and more intense heat-waves, more severe droughts, and a shift in rainfall patterns. Malta's agriculture is already suffering from increasingly unpredictable weather patterns. Rising sea levels pose a grave threat to Malta's coastal areas, which are heavily developed for tourism and residential purposes.

articles.title: Economy, federal cuts worry Anne Arundel residents, poll finds
articles.author: James Matheson
articles.summary: Economic impacts from President Donald Trump's restructuring of the federal government are among the most pressing concerns for Anne Arundel County residents, according to a survey from the community college's survey of residents. The survey was conducted on behalf of the Anne Aroden County Community College.

articles.title: Mid-century Emission Cuts Key to Curb Sea-level Rise
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Emissions released in the coming decades will determine how much coastlines are reshaped for centuries to come. Near-term mitigation could spare future generations around 0.6 meters of sea-level rise between 2020 and 2090. Today's decisions are critical for limiting warming and for coastal impacts.

articles.title: Countries press ahead with climate goals despite Trump's agenda, but progress is slow
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Marshall Islands' land is 7 feet above sea level because of climate change. The world is not on track to stop rising global temperatures despite 30 years of international climate talks and 10 years of a global treaty promising to keep temperatures in check. China is the world's largest greenhouse gas emitter, but it is also the fastest-growing economy. The EU has made waves by extending its carbon pricing rules beyond its borders, but some member states are moving away from it.

articles.title: This is the population boom we're not talking about
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: The population of Melbourne's west is expected to double to 1.8 million people by 2050. That's more than two-thirds the size of Brisbane and almost twice as many people as there are people in Melbourne's east now.

articles.title: Bird Flu likely cause of death for hundreds of seal pups on sub-Antarctic island
articles.summary: Hundreds of dead elephant seal pups have been found on Heard Island in the sub-Antarctic. The virus H5N1 has spread through wild bird and mammal populations since 2021, killing millions and infecting poultry and dairy farms. Australia is the only continent free of the highly contagious virus.

articles.title: Major Emission Cuts Key to Curb Sea-Level Rise
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: New research shows that near-term mitigation could spare future generations around 0.6 meters of sea-level rise between 2020 and 2090. Emissions released in the coming decades will determine how much coastlines are reshaped for centuries to come. Some regions like the Pacific Islands will experience even higher sea level rise than the global average.

articles.title: Column: Complaining warms you twice
articles.author: Doug Brendel
articles.summary: Summer in Ipswich is hot and smelly in the summertime. You can't take any more clothes off without getting divorced or arrested, so you have to wear the flimsiest clothes you own or you will get arrested or divorced or both.

articles.title: Destructive Bird Flu Threatens Antarctic Wildlife
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Hundreds of dead seal pups found on Heard Island are suspected to be the result of H5N1 bird flu. The virus is responsible for wildlife fatalities across the globe. Samples from the pups will be analyzed in Australia for confirmation. Australia remains free from the virus, but concerns rise as further spread through Antarctica elevates the risk of southern infections.

articles.title: Bird flu likely killed hundreds of seal pups on sub-Antarctic island
articles.author: Peter Hobson
articles.summary: Hundreds of dead elephant seal pups found on Heard Island in the sub-Antarctic by Australian scientists. H5N1 bird flu has spread through wild bird and mammal populations since 2021, killing millions and infecting poultry and dairy farms. Australia is the only continent free of the highly contagious virus.

articles.title: Warm Halloween and winter start defy Autumn chills in HK
articles.author: The Standard 英文虎報
articles.summary: sugar as world gets hotter, according to a study by the American Institute of Health.    for more sugar.  for less sugar for more fat for more calories.  For more sugar for less fat for less calories. For more information, go to:

articles.title: South Sudan: No end in sight - floods in Greater Pibor already displaced over 43000 people
articles.author: APO
articles.summary: In South Sudan, the cascading effects of climate change have become increasingly visible and devastating with torrential rainfall displacing communities all across the country. In regions like the Greater Pibor Administrative Area, high-water levels have surged across six counties, threatening to tip.

articles.title: Climatic Divergence and Rainfall Extremes in Kerala
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Climatic divergence in the Indian Western Ghats has been studied by K, N., Chaturvedi, A.K., and Sabu. They found significant variances in rainfall extremes between the Northern and Southern peaks of the mountain ranges in Kerala. The study highlights the threats that shifting rainfall patterns pose to endemic species in the region. Decision-makers need to create adaptive strategies that mitigate the adverse effects of climatic divergence.

articles.title: Research Finds Two Coral Species Functionally Extinct in Florida
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: 2023 heatwave devastated Florida's coral reefs. Staghorn and elkhorn corals have been declared functionally extinct. It was the highest temperatures ever recorded on Florida's Coral Reef in over 150 years. Heat exposure levels were 2.2 to 4 times greater than in any previous year on record.

articles.title: Governor takes aim at tax barrier to economic mobility
articles.author: Jack Gramenz
articles.summary: "The number of new housing dwelling completions in the most expensive city in Australia and the second most expensive in the world has not been anywhere near good enough," says the housing minister.    "The new housing dwellings completions" in Melbourne are not good enough.

articles.title: The Panel with Penny Ashton and Nick Leggett, Part 1
articles.summary: Tonight on The Panel, Wallace Chapman is joined by panellists Penny Ashton and Nick Leggett. They check in with the Student Volunteer Army in Invercargill as they enter clean-up mode from this week's devastating weather. Climate Scientist Dr Nathanael Melia joins The Panel. ACT MP Laura McClure's bill to criminalise sexually explicit 'deepfake' images has been drawn from the biscuit bin.

articles.title: Deadly H5 strain of bird flu suspected on sub-Antarctic Heard Island in the Southern Ocean
articles.author: Antarctic reporter
articles.summary: Scientists fear H5 bird flu has reached sub-Antarctic Heard Island after signs of the disease were seen in elephant seals on Heard Island during a management voyage to the island. The disease is a deadly strain of bird flu that can be transmitted by infected birds.

articles.title: Tens of millions of red crabs begin annual migration to ocean on Christmas Island
articles.summary: Up to 100 million red crabs are migrating from forest burrows to the ocean on Christmas Island, Australia. Park staff assist the crabs with leaf blowers and garden rakes during this remarkable annual event, triggered by the summer rains.

articles.title: Peatlands' Carbon Reservoir Faces Release Threat
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Peatlands store more than 30% of the world's soil carbon. Extreme drought increases the release of carbon in peatlands by nearly three times. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change estimates extreme drought will become 1.7 to 7.2 times more likely in the near future.

articles.title: Tourist's death from 'harmless' sharks highlights simple actions that can trigger 'feeding frenzy'
articles.author: Michael Dahlstrom
articles.summary: Dusky sharks killed a tourist off the coast of Hadera, north of Tel Aviv, Israel, in April. Dr Gavin Naylor is the world's foremost expert in shark attacks. He says changes to environment can affect the behaviour of almost any animal species, sometimes bringing them into conflict with humans.

articles.title: In a California farming region, researchers map heat to protect farmworkers
articles.summary: Researchers from San Diego State University are working to understand how climate change is impacting heat in rural areas and farmworkers who toil in them.       .   in some of the most agriculturally rich regions in the U.S.

articles.title: Data shows the Amazon is faltering — yet the satellite that spotted this may soon be shut down
articles.author: Paul Palmer
articles.summary: OCO-2 is at risk of being shut down due to proposed Nasa budget cut. CO₂ in the atmosphere grew by 3.73ppm in 2024, faster than in any year since records began. Warming temperatures explain most of the reduced activity of the Amazon rainforest.

articles.title: Signs of deadly bird flu strain in seals on Australian sub-Antarctic Heard Island
articles.author: Blake Antrobus
articles.summary: A possible H5 avian flu strain has been found on Heard Island in Australia's sub-Antarctic islands. There are biosecurity concerns and warnings of a 'wake-up call' from scientists on board the RSV Nuyina.

articles.title: Arctic tern: Natureâs longest traveller and the secrets behind its epic journey
articles.author: TOI Trending Desk
articles.summary: The Arctic tern's migration from the Arctic to the Antarctic and back is the longest known migration on Earth. Scientists used tracking devices to track the migration of terns breeding in Prince William Sound, Alaska. The terns followed a precise southward route along the Pacific coast, stopping at ocean regions rich in food. They stopped at the California Current, the Humboldt Current near Peru and Chile, and the Patagonian Shelf before heading to Antarctica.

articles.title: 'We are surrounded': Australia prepares for 'deadly virus' expected on shores soon
articles.author: Lanie Tindale
articles.summary: Greg Brown's Canberra egg farmer is preparing for a very deadly H5 bird flu. The virus has travelled the world and now sits on the country's doorstep. ACT Environment Minister Suzanne Orr warned that it could cripple farmers and disrupt food supply chains. There are also fears that some endangered species could be wiped out.

articles.title: 'We are surrounded': Australia prepares for 'deadly virus' expected on shores soon
articles.author: Lanie Tindale
articles.summary: As the weather warms up, most Australians are happy to put the flu season behind them and are looking forward to warmer weather and less people getting sicker.       .   for confidential support call the Samaritans in Australia on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details.

articles.title: 'We are surrounded': Australia prepares for 'deadly virus' expected on shores soon
articles.author: Lanie Tindale
articles.summary: Greg Brown's Canberra egg farm was quarantined for three months during the H7 bird flu outbreak last year. If one of his 2000 pasteurised hens tests positive to H5, he will have to cull the entire flock. Environment Minister Suzanne Orr warns that the H5 bird flu could cripple farmers and disrupt food supply chains. The Commonwealth has invested $100 million preparing for the flu.

articles.title: Taking on the Algal Bloom
articles.author: Hui Jin
articles.summary: The algal bloom on the south coast of Finniss has disappeared. David Basham is a member for Finniss. He is at the water's edge at the time of the disappearance of the bloom. He's looking for the source of the water.

articles.title: Deadly H5 strain of bird flu suspected on sub-Antarctic Heard Island in the Southern Ocean
articles.author: Antarctic reporter
articles.summary: There are suspected cases of H5 bird flu on Heard Island in the Southern Ocean. Wildlife experts travelled to the volcanic island on the icebreaker RSV Nuyina. The ship will return to Australia in mid-November with samples for testing. Australia is the only continent free from HPAI.

articles.title: State of Climate Action Report shows record clean-energy investments still inadequate to check temperature rise. Upcoming COP 30 must address i
articles.author: Editorial
articles.summary: The State of Climate Action Report shows that the world is moving in the right direction towards the Paris Climate Change Pact's goals, but at a slower pace than desired. Renewable energy produced more than 50% of the electricity generated in the first half of this year, but the share of fossil fuel in the energy mix went down. US President Donald Trump's efforts to halt low-carbon projects are yet to make themselves felt in the form of more GHG emissions.

articles.title: New Study Determines It Is ‘Impossible' For CO2 To Be The Driving Mechanism In Global Warming
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: Only 1% of global warming is indicated by an increase in surface air temperatures. The rise in ocean heat content (OHC) since 1955 cannot be attributed to linearly-rising CO2 emissions. OHC changes manifest short-term 'periods with a very strong +0.8 W/m² radiation imbalance (1970-1980), but also a period with an almost perfect radiation balance (1980-1990).

articles.title: Fearing repeat of Beryl flooding, Waterford residents want Adair Drive gully cleaned and repaired
articles.summary: Residents of Waterford in Portmore, St. Catherine, are concerned about the condition of the Adair Drive drainage channel. The gully has not been properly maintained for years. Last year Hurricane Beryl caused major flooding in Waterford. Councillor for the Waterford Division, Fenley Douglas, has been asking for years for a maintenance programme to be put in place so that the drain is cleaned once a year.

articles.title: Democratising Climate Finance: Why the Green Climate Fund Must Embrace Small-scale Solutions
articles.summary: Green Climate Fund (GCF) is the world's largest dedicated climate finance mechanism with over $10 billion in pledged resources. However, it does not provide access to the funding mechanisms for grassroots actors closest to climate impacts. Community-level interventions offer advantages that complement macro-level investments.

articles.title: Australia Investigates Possible H5 Bird Flu Outbreak on Sub-Antarctic Island
articles.author: Dr. Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: Heard Island, a remote sub-Antarctic territory in the Southern Ocean, has reported an elevated mortality among elephant seals. The H5 strain of bird flu has been proliferating amongst wild bird populations globally. The virus was detected in Indonesia in 2022 and in Antarctica in 2023. It is a major concern for public health and agricultural industries globally.

articles.title: Minnesota to update plan to combat climate change
articles.author: Duluth News Tribune
articles.summary: 2026 draft of the Minnesota Climate Action Framework will include additional modeling of greenhouse gas emission scenarios. Officials are updating the three-year-old document guiding state agencies' response to climate change. Minnesotans want to see climate action, the draft says.

articles.title: Labor's fossil fuel addiction puts Australia in terrible company
articles.author: Bernard Keane
articles.summary: The prime minister's views on the need to add a climate trigger to the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act have changed over the past 20 years. The climate change trigger will enable major new projects to be assessed for their climate change impact as part of any environmental assessment process.

articles.title: Rising risks at sea: South Korea's fishing crews face a surge in deadly accidents
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Last year, 164 people were killed or went missing in accidents in waters around South Korea, a 75% rise on the year before. The government set up a taskforce to investigate the cause of the increase. Climate change is one of the main drivers of the accidents. There are also structural and operational problems in the industry, including an ageing fishing population, growing reliance on migrant workers, and insufficient safety training.

articles.title: World hits first tipping point
articles.author: The Echo
articles.summary: According to the 2025 Global Tipping Points Report, we have reached our first climate change tipping point. Warm water coral reefs are crossing their thermal tipping point and experiencing unprecedented dieback at 1.40C of global warming. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), tipping points are critical thresholds in a system that when exceeded can lead to a significant change in the state of the system. The report recommends 'unprecedented acceleration in decarbonisation' and addressing non-climate drivers.

articles.title: Labor's Proposed Environmental Protection Agency Faces Tough Run Through Senate
articles.author: Naziya Alvi Rahman
articles.summary: The Albanese Labor government's latest attempt to overhaul Australia's environmental laws has run into turbulence before even reaching Parliament. The proposed rewrite of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC) Act has drawn criticism from both the Coalition and the Greens for entirely different reasons.

articles.title: Australia on alert as deadly H5 bird flu suspected on sub-Antarctic island
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: Heard Island, 4000 km southwest of Perth, has signs of H5 avian influenza. The virus has previously been found on the French Kerguelen and Crozet sub-Antarctic islands 450 km from Heard and McDonald islands. Australia is the only continent in the world free of the H5 strain of bird flu.

articles.title: Deadly bird flu fear on remote Australian island
articles.summary: Heard Island, 4000 km southwest of Perth, has signs of H5 avian influenza. The virus has previously been found on the French Kerguelen and Crozet sub-Antarctic islands 450 km from Heard and McDonald islands. Australia is the only continent in the world free of the H5 strain of bird flu.

articles.title: Experts warn that iconic US coastal destination could soon disappear from map: 'It is a major challenge'
articles.author: Robert Crow
articles.summary: Rising sea levels could have catastrophic impacts on the San Francisco Bay. Patrick Barnard, a coastal-climate research director at the University of California, Santa Cruz, recently published another study on the Bay Area in the Journal of Waterway, Port, Coastal, and Ocean Engineering. His previous research found that 400,000 residents and $150 billion in property could be exposed to flooding this century in California. By combining several flood-mitigation strategies, such as restoring wetlands and adding flood gates, the region could help keep its cities and residents safe.

articles.title: Signs of deadly bird flu observed by gov't scientists on Australian sub-Antarctic island
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Scientists have observed signs of H5 bird flu in elephant seals on Heard Island. The island is located in the Southern Ocean about 4,000 km southwest of the Australian mainland and 1,700 km north of Antarctica. The government has committed over 100 million Australian dollars to boost Australia's preparedness for a bird flu outbreak.

articles.title: ‘Climate funding target unlikely to be met'
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Former Maldivian President Nasheed warns that climate change is a serious problem. He is concerned about the future of the country and its people. He also believes in renewable energy sources.    "I am concerned about climate change. I believe in sustainable development."

articles.title: South Korea's fishermen keep dying. Is climate change to blame?
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: climate change is partly to blame for an increase in deadly incidents, an inquiry found.    .   for the increase in deaths is partly caused by climate change.  For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch or click here.

articles.title: Scientists Observe Signs of H5 Bird Flu in Antarctic Wildlife
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Scientists have observed signs consistent with H5 avian influenza (bird flu) in wildlife during a management voyage to sub-Antarctic Heard Island. Suspicions have not yet been confirmed, but the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry says there are concerns.

articles.title: Scientists in Switzerland say 1.5C climate change goal is out of reach: Survey
articles.author: Beyza Binnur Donmez
articles.summary: Scientists in Switzerland don't expect the world to limit warming to 1.5C (2.7F), the key target set under the Paris Agreement. Switzerland is warming twice as fast as the global average. More than 90% of glaciers are projected to disappear, threatening water supplies, agriculture, and hydropower.

articles.title: LexisNexis U.S. Home Insurance Trends Report Highlights Rising Peril Severity as Catastrophic Claims Hit Seven-Year High
articles.author: Laurel Leader-Call
articles.summary: impact of hurricanes, hail and flooding continues to rise.    in 25th century.  in 20th century  in which the severity and loss costs continue to climb  in number of people affected by these events.  In   century in which they increase in number.

articles.title: TMID Editorial: Climate change and small islands
articles.author: The Malta Independent
articles.summary: The Earth's climate is changing. This has profound implications for small island nations, especially for the climate of small island states. The changes are due to the changing climate of the Earth's atmosphere and oceans. The effects of climate change on small island countries have profound implications.

articles.title: Global Warming Coalition to hold meeting on climate challenges
articles.author: The Roseburg News-Review
articles.summary: Douglas County Global Warming Coalition has an upcoming forum on climate change adaptation and resiliency with an emphasis on wildfires next week in Roseburg, Douglas County, next week. The forum will focus on wildfire prevention and adaptation, with emphasis on Douglas County.

articles.title: Global warming pushes Earth's tipping points toward critical thresholds
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Rising global temperatures are driving the planet's tipping points toward critical thresholds that could trigger irreversible climate changes, according to Levent Kurnaz, director of Bogazici University's Center for Climate Change and Policy Research. As global warming raises the average atmospheric temperature, it raises the tipping points.

articles.title: Why has IUCN red-flagged the Western Ghats?
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: There are many threats to the UNESCO World Heritage Site, tourism, climate change, hydropower plants and other issues. It is threatened by tourism and climate change. It's threatened by many things, including the loss of its natural resources and its water resources.

articles.title: Indian Farmers Struggle as Climate Change Warps Landscape
articles.author: Foreign Policy
articles.summary: Once-thriving crops are poorly adapting to new temperatures and are not growing well.       .   in the new climate is affecting the crops.  in this way, they are not producing well in the current climate. in the future, they will not grow.
